THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Michael R.
          Gartside, Respondent/Appellant
        v.
        Ellen T.
          Gartside, Appellant/Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Jane D. Fender, Family Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  4537
  Heard March 17, 2009 â€“ Filed April 29,
2009

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        H. Stanley Feldman, of Charleston, for Appellant/Respondent.
        Paul Daniel Schwartz, of Charleston, for Respondent/Appellant.
      
    
  

WILLIAMS, J.: In this family law action, we determine
  whether the family court erred in (1) reducing Michael Gartside's (Husband)
  alimony obligation and (2) failing to award attorneys' fees and costs to
  Husband.Â  We affirm.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Husband
  and Ellen Gartside (Wife) divorced in 2003.Â  At the time of the divorce,
  Husband was employed by the Carolina Yacht Club (the Club) and Wife was
  employed as a public school teacher.Â  The final decree stated Husband and Wife
  earned gross monthly wages of $9,079 and $3,814, respectively.Â  The final
  decree awarded Wife periodic alimony in the amount of $1,775 per month.Â  
At
  the time of the divorce, Husband had been making $108,948 per year at the Club
  according to his financial declaration.Â  From December 18, 2003 until October
  1, 2005, Husband made his alimony payments to Wife.Â  However, Husband
  lost his job at the Club in October 2005, at which time he was making between
  $105,000 and $106,000, according to his testimony.[1]Â 
  After being let go by the Club, Husband found a job working for the Muhler
  Company (Muhler) in November 2005, where he received a reported salary of
  $60,000 per year.Â  
On
  January 17, 2006, Husband, through counsel, mailed Wife a letter advising her
  he would be able to continue paying the current alimony onlyÂ  through April 28,
  2006, with his severance package from the Club, but thereafter, he would be
  unable to continue to pay the $1,775 per month.Â  
On March 17, 2006,
  Husband filed an action in the Charleston County family court seeking a reduction
  in his alimony obligation, alleging a substantial and material change in
  circumstances.Â  The complaint alleged that Husband had only been able to
  maintain his alimony payments because of his severance package, which was to
  expire in April 2006.Â  
The
  case was tried in April 2007 before the family court.Â Â  Husband and Wife
  submitted their financial declarations to the family court and testified as to
  their respective financial situations.Â  As of February 1, 2007, Husband's gross
  monthly income was $5,200, while his net monthly income was $3,488.Â  His total
  monthly expenses were $7,372.Â  As of February 18, 2007, Wife's gross monthly
  income was $5,249, while her net monthly income was $3,787.Â  Her total monthly
  expenses were $4,045.Â  
At
  trial, Husband was asked about his efforts at finding employment after the Club
  terminated him.Â  Husband testified that "hundred thousand dollar club
  jobs" existed in the tri-county area, but none were available.Â  At one
  point, Husband submitted his resume to the Country Club of Charleston, but was
  not offered a position.Â  Husband further testified he believed jobs within his
  profession existed outside of the tri-county area that would pay approximately
  what the Club had paid.Â  Husband made no efforts, however, to interview outside
  of the tri-county area.Â  Husband also testified that, before settling in
  Charleston in 1982, he had relocated to Pennsylvania, Colorado, Georgia, and
  Texas, all in furtherance of his career.Â  
After
  considering all of the evidence, the family court reduced Husband's alimony
  obligation from $1,775 per month to $800 per month.Â  The court stated:

  [Husband
    and Wife] moved to Charleston, S.C., in 1982 . . . . [T]hey have raised their
    children here, have owned property here, have had their work careers here, have
    put down roots, have made friends and have established themselves as citizens
    of Charleston County[,] and if [they] were still living together and [Husband]
    had lost his job, I have serious doubts they would move away just so they could
    continue making the same salary . . . .
  [Husband]
    testified that there were no comparable jobs available in the Charleston
    area[,] . . . and I find no compelling reason that [Husband] should be forced
    to leave the environment he has known for 25 years to seek employment which
    might pay the same as he was receiving in Charleston at his previous
    employment.

Husband
  submitted an affidavit in support of his request for attorneys' fees and costs,
  which the family court denied.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An
  appellate court reviewing a family court order may find facts in accordance
  with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence. Robinson v. Tyson,
  319 S.C. 360, 362, 461 S.E.2d 397, 398-99 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  This broad scope of
  review does not, however, require the reviewing court to disregard the findings
  of the family court, which, having seen and heard the witnesses, is in a better
  position to examine their credibility.Â  Skinner v. King, 272 S.C. 520,
  522-23, 252 S.E.2d 891, 892 (1979). Â Nor does this broad review relieve an
  appellant of his or her burden of convincing the appellate court that the
  family court committed error.Â  Id. at 523, 252 S.E.2d at 892. 
LAW/ANALYSIS
1. Whether the family court
  erred in reducing Husband's alimony obligations?
Wife
  argues the family court abused its discretion in reducing Husband's alimony
  obligation.Â  We disagree.
The
  purpose of alimony is to provide the ex-spouse a substitute for the support that
  was incident to the former marital relationship.Â  Croom v. Croom, 305
  S.C. 158, 160, 406 S.E.2d 381, 382 (Ct. App. 1991).Â  The question of whether to
  increase or decrease alimony based on a finding of changed circumstances is a
  matter committed to the sound discretion of the family court.Â  Brunner v.
    Brunner, 296 S.C. 60, 64, 370 S.E.2d 614, 617 (Ct. App. 1988). Â The family
  court's determination of whether to modify support will not be disturbed on
  appeal unless the family court abused its discretion. Â Id.Â  An abuse of
  discretion occurs when the family court's decision is controlled by some error
  of law or where the order, based upon findings of fact, is without evidentiary
  support. McKnight v. McKnight, 283 S.C. 540, 543, 324 S.E.2d 91, 93 (Ct.
  App. 1984).
In
  order to justify a modification of an alimony award, the changes in
  circumstances must be substantial or material.Â  Thornton v. Thornton,
  328 S.C. 96, 111, 492 S.E.2d 86, 94 (1997) (citing Calvert v. Calvert,
  287 S.C. 130, 138, 336 S.E.2d 884, 888 (Ct. App. 1985)).Â  In determining
  whether the change in circumstances warrants a modification, several
  considerations relevant to the initial determination of an alimony award may be
  applied in the modification context as well, including the parties' standard of
  living during the marriage, each party's earning capacity, and the supporting
  spouse's ability to continue to support the payee spouse.Â  Penny v. Green,
  357 S.C. 583, 589, 594 S.E.2d 171, 174 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  
We agree
  with the family court that Husband's change of circumstances constitutes a substantial
  and material change.Â  Moreover, because we find evidentiary support for its
  decision, we see no abuse of discretion in the family court's lowering Husband's
  alimony obligations from $1,775 per month to $800 per month.Â  First, Husband's
  annual income has been reduced from $108,948 at the time of the divorce to
  $60,000.Â  See Miles v. Miles, 355 S.C. 511, 519, 586 S.E.2d 136,
  140 (Ct. App. 2003) (affirming family court's reduction in ex-husband's monthly
  alimony from $4,583 to $2,500 in light of the fact ex-husband's monthly income
  had been reduced from $18,100 to less than $14,000).Â  Second, because Husband's
  income was reduced to $60,000 per year, his monthly expenses now exceed his
  monthly income by almost $4,000.Â  Therefore, even if Husband were to cut out some
  of what Wife describes as his "discretionary" expenses, he would
  still remain in debt at the end of each month.Â  Third, Wife's overall financial
  situation has arguably improved since the divorce.Â  Not only have her monthly
  wages increased slightly since the divorce from $3,263 to $3,474, but she
  testified she is no longer receiving medical treatment for her emotional
  condition, which she was at the time of the divorce.Â  Taken together, we find
  these facts support the family court's decision to lower Husband's alimony
  obligation.
2. Whether Husband's former
  income should have been imputed?

  a. Preservation

Husband
  argues this issue is not preserved for appeal because it was not raised to the
  family court prior to Wife's Rule 59(e), SCRCP, motion to alter judgment.Â  We disagree.Â  
But
  for a very few exceptional circumstances, an appellate court cannot address an
  issue unless it was raised to and ruled upon by the family court.Â  Lucas v.
    Rawl Family Ltd. P'ship, 359 S.C. 505, 510-11, 598 S.E.2d 712, 715 (2004).Â 
  "Imposing this preservation requirement on the appellant is meant to
  enable the lower court to rule properly after it has considered all relevant
  facts, law, and arguments."Â  I'On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mount Pleasant,
  338 S.C. 406, 422, 526 S.E.2d 716, 724 (2000). Â As such, a party cannot use a Rule
  59(e) motion to present to the family court an issue the party could have
  raised prior to judgment but did not. Â Crary v. Djebelli, 321 S.C. 38,
  43, 467 S.E.2d 128, 131-32 (Ct. App. 1995), rev'd on other grounds, 329
  S.C. 385, 496 S.E.2d 21 (1998).
Although
  the first time the phrase "whether income should be imputed" appeared
  in the pleadings was in Wife's Rule 59(e) motion, we feel this issue is
  nevertheless preserved because the issue of imputed income was both raised to
  and ruled upon by the family court.Â  First, counsel for Wife asserted at trial
  that "the number one consideration [in this case] is that [Husband] is
  underemployed" because "[Husband] chooses to stay with his fiancÃ©e in
  Charleston and not . . . look anywhere else."Â  Underemployment and
  imputation of income go hand in hand.Â  See Patel v. Patel, 359
  S.C. 515, 532, 599 S.E.2d 114, 123 (2004) ("It is proper to impute income
  to a party who is voluntarily unemployed or underemployed."); Penny,
  357 S.C. at 592, 594 S.E.2d at 175 ("The family court's imputation of
  income to Husband was tantamount to finding Husband underemployed.").Â  Thus,
  by raising the issue of underemployment, we believe Wife sufficiently raised
  the issue of income imputation.Â  Second, the issue of income imputation was
  ruled upon by the family court when it justified its alimony reduction, at
  least in part, by the fact that there "were no comparable jobs available
  in the Charleston area" and there was "no compelling reason that
  [Husband] should be forced to leave the environment he has known for 25 years
  to seek employment which might pay the same as he was receiving in
  Charleston."Â  This was an implicit rejection of the argument that Husband
  was underemployed.Â  See Pryor v. Nw. Apartments, Ltd., 321 S.C.
  524, 528 n.2, 469 S.E.2d 630, 633 n.2 (Ct. App. 1996) (finding an issue
  preserved when the circuit court implicitly ruled on and rejected the
  respondent's argument).Â  Â Accordingly, we find the issue is preserved.

  b. Merits

Wife
  argues the family court erred in failing to impute to Husband an income
  comparable to that of his former position at the Club when modifying his
  alimony obligations.Â  We disagree.
Whether
  termed voluntary underemployment, imputation of income, or the failure to reach
  earning potential, the case law is clear that when a payor spouse seeks to
  reduce support obligations based on his diminished income, a court should
  consider the payor spouse's earning capacity. Â Kelley v. Kelley, 324
  S.C. 481, 488, 477 S.E.2d 727, 731 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  The failure to reach
  earning capacity, by itself, does not automatically equate to voluntary
  underemployment such that income must be imputed.Â  Id. at 488-89, 477
  S.E.2d at 731.Â  Although some of the precedents appear inconsistent, the common
  thread in cases when actual income versus earning capacity is at issue is that
  courts must closely examine the payor spouse's good faith and reasonable
  explanation for the decreased income.Â  Id. at 489, 477 S.E.2d at 731; see Mazzone v. Miles, 341 S.C. 203, 209, 532 S.E.2d 890, 893 (Ct. App. 2000)
  (declining to impute more than minimum wage to husband when there was no
  evidence that the loss of his job was due to any wrongdoing, or that his
  decision to start his own business was motivated by a desire to avoid his child
  support obligations).Â  However, a payor spouse can be found to be voluntarily
  underemployed even in the absence of a bad faith motivation.Â  Arnal v. Arnal,
  371 S.C. 10, 13, 636 S.E.2d 864, 866 (2006).Â  
Here,
  Wife does not dispute Husband lost his job at the Club through no fault of his
  own.Â  Husband networked for other club positions in the Charleston area but
  found no other positions available.Â  At one point, Husband submitted his resume
  to the Country Club of Charleston, but to no avail.Â  Other than this, Husband
  has not pursued positions at any other clubs outside of Charleston.Â  Instead,
  he accepted employment outside of his profession at Muhler at a much lower
  salary than he received at the Club.Â  Husband's explanation for not pursuing
  employment at his former salary is that he does not wish to relocate from
  Charleston, where he has lived since 1982.Â  As the family court pointed out,
  Husband "ha[s] put down roots, ha[s] made friends and ha[s] established
  [himself] as [a] citizen[] of Charleston County."Â  We find this to be a
  good faith, reasonable explanation for his reduced income.
To
  impute to Husband his former income in this case would essentially force him to
  move outside of Charleston.Â  Courts are reluctant to invade a party's freedom
  to pursue the employment path of their own choice or impose unreasonable
  demands upon parties.Â  Kelley, 324 S.C. at 489, 477 S.E.2d at 731; see
    also LaFrance v. LaFrance, 370 S.C. 622, 647, 636 S.E.2d 3, 16 (Ct.
  App. 2006) (holding the family court erred by imputing $100,000 income to
  husband when the available positions identified by wife's expert witness as
  paying that salary would all require husband to move away from his current
  residence and his three minor children).Â  Other jurisdictions are similarly
  reluctant to impute income based on the availability of jobs that require
  relocation.Â  See Budnick v. Budnick, 595 S.E.2d 50, 59 (Va. Ct.
  App. 2004) (finding no error in trial court's refusal to impute lost income to
  wife who refused to accept a job transfer to a different city within the
  state).
Furthermore,
  the South Carolina Child Support Guidelines (the Guidelines) address the issue
  of determining earning capacity.Â  The Guidelines define "income" as "the
  actual gross income of the parent if employed to full capacity, or potential
  income if unemployed or underemployed." S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 114-4720(A)
  (Supp. 2008). The Guidelines further provide:

  In
    order to impute income to a parent who is unemployed or underemployed, the
    court should determine the employment potential and probable earning level of
    the parent based on that parent's recent work history, occupational
    qualifications and prevailing job opportunities and earning levels in the
      community.

Id. (emphasis added).Â  This suggests that, in determining
  earning capacity for purposes of imputing income, a community standard should
  be applied when determining the availability of employment.Â  
In
  sum, we find no error in the family court's decision not to impute to Husband
  his former income.
3. Whether the trial court
  erred in reducing Husband's alimony obligations by 55% when Husband's loss of
  income was approximately 40%?
Wife
  argues even if the reduction in alimony, in and of itself, was not an abuse of
  discretion, the family court nevertheless abused its discretion in reducing
  Husband's alimony obligations by fifty-five percent when Husband's loss of
  income was only forty percent.Â  However, Wife has cited no legal authority to
  support the argument that this was an error of law.Â  As such, this argument is
  conclusory, and such arguments are deemed abandoned on appeal.Â  See Mulherin-Howell
    v. Cobb, 362 S.C. 588, 600, 608 S.E.2d 587, 593-94 (Ct. App. 2005) (finding
  party abandoned an issue on appeal due to failure to cite any supporting
  authority and making only conclusory arguments).
4. Whether the family court
  erred in failing to award Husband attorneys' fees and costs?
Husband
  argues the family court abused its discretion in refusing to award him attorneys'
  fees and costs.Â  We disagree.
An
  award of attorneys' fees rests within the sound discretion of the family court
  and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Upchurch
    v. Upchurch, 367 S.C. 16, 28, 624 S.E.2d 643, 648 (2006).Â  In determining
  whether attorneys' fees should be awarded, the following factors should be
  considered: (1) the party's ability to pay his or her own attorneys' fee; (2) the
  beneficial results obtained by the attorney; (3) the parties' respective
  financial conditions; and (4) the effect of the attorneys' fees on each party's
  standard of living.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 476-77, 415 S.E.2d
  812, 816 (1992) (citing Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161, 403
  S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991)).Â  A beneficial result will not secure an award of attorneys'
  fees where the other factors do not support such an award.Â  Mazzone, 341
  S.C. at 214, 532 S.E.2d at 895.
The
  family court considered the appropriate factors in its final order and held
  that "each party should be responsible for paying his and her own respective
  attorneys' fees."Â  Although Husband's attorney obtained a beneficial
  result, we believe in light of the other factors, the family court did not
  abuse its discretion in denying Husband's request for attorneys' fees.Â 
  According to Husband's affidavit in support of attorneys' fees and costs, his
  attorneys' fees totaled $12,064.92.Â  According to Wife's financial declaration
  dated February 18, 2007, she earns a gross income of only $3,474 per month as a
  school teacher.Â  Thus, Husband's attorneys' fees represent over three months
  worth of pay for Wife.Â  Moreover, Wife is in no better position to pay
  Husband's fees than Husband is to pay his own, as Husband earns $60,000 per
  year at Muhler.Â  Accordingly, we find the family court did not abuse its
  discretion in refusing to award Husband attorneys' fees and costs.
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, the family court's decision is 
AFFIRMED.
HUFF and KONDUROS, JJ., concur.


[1] The parties do
  not dispute Husband lost his job at the Club through no fault of his own.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				South Carolina
      Department of Social Services, Respondent,
				v.
				Janice C.,
      Henry M., Willie B., George T., Stanley E., John Doe, John Roe, and John Joe, Defendants,
				Of Whom Janice
      C. and Stanley E. are the Appellants.
				In the
      interests of:
				B.C., A.C., B.C., J.C., and N.C., minor children under the age of
  18. 
			
		
	


Opinion No. 4538
Heard January 22, 2009 â€“ Filed April 30,
  2009
AFFIRM IN PART AND REVERSE IN PART

Appeal from Williamsburg County
Â R. Wright Turbeville, Family Court Judge

	
		
			
				Charles Thomas Brooks and Irma R. Brooks, both of Sumter, for Appellants.
			  Helen McFadden, of Kingstree, for Respondent.
			
	  
	

LOCKEMY,
  J.:Â  This is an expedited termination of parental rights
    (TPR) action pursuant to section 20-7-1572 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2007) (current version
  at 63-7-2570 (Supp. 2008)).[1]Â  Janice C. (Mother) appeals
  the family courtâ€™s order terminating her parental rights as to her five
  children (Children).Â  Stanley E. (Father) appeals the family courtâ€™s
  termination of his parental rights as to his child, N.C.Â  We reverse the family
  court's TPR of Mother and affirm the family court's TPR of Father.Â  
FACTUAL / PROCEDURAL
  BACKGROUND
Mother is a
  mentally disabled single mother of five special needs children, ages eleven,
  nine, eight, seven, and four. Â Each child has a different father.Â  Father is
  the father of Motherâ€™s youngest child, N.C. 
In
  2004, the Williamsburg County Department of Social Services (DSS) took Children
  into emergency protective custody. At the time of removal, two of the children
  lived with Mother and three of the children lived with their maternal
  grandmother (Grandmother).[2]Â  The family court found Motherâ€™s home had no water and no electricity, and
  Mother was behind in her rent.Â  Grandmotherâ€™s home had no water, no stove, and
  weak and sagging floors. Â Â In addition, Grandmother was diabetic and had badly
  swollen knees.Â  Ultimately, the family court held there was probable cause for
  law enforcement to take emergency protective custody of Children. 
DSS developed a
  treatment plan for Mother and Grandmother.Â  Motherâ€™s treatment plan required
  Mother to secure and maintain appropriate housing, enroll at the South Carolina
  Department of Disabilities and Special Needs, and complete parenting
  effectiveness training classes. The family court approved the treatment plan,
  finding Mother "made some progress toward removing the risk of harm to the
  minor children." Grandmother passed away during the course of this
  action.
Father
  began visiting and supporting his daughter, N.C., in 2006.Â  He had little
  contact with N.C. prior to that time.Â  Father informed DSS that he was unable
  to take N.C. because he did not have his own home.Â  Instead, Father suggested
  DSS place N.C. with Fatherâ€™s adult daughter, Brandy. Â Â Although Brandy
  initially expressed an interest in N.C., Brandy later told DSS she wanted
  Father to take a paternity test to prove N.C. was her sister. Â Â Father refused
  to take a paternity test.Â  Ultimately, DSS did not offer Father a treatment
  plan because his parental rights had been terminated as to other children in
  the past. 
DSS initiated a
  termination of parental rights (TPR) action against Mother, Father, and several
  other biological fathers in January 2007. Â In May 2007, the family court
  terminated Motherâ€™s parental rights to Children after finding termination was
  in the best interest of Children and the following statutory grounds: (1)
  Children lived outside of Motherâ€™s home for six months and Mother failed to
  remedy the conditions that caused the removal; (2) Mother had a diagnosable
  condition unlikely to change within a reasonable time and the condition made
  Mother unlikely to provide minimally acceptable care of Children; (3) Mother
  neglected Children, and because of the severity or repetition of the abuse or
  neglect, it was not likely the home could be made safe within twelve months;
  and (4) Children had been in foster care for fifteen of the most recent
  twenty-two months. Â 
The
  family court relied on the testimony of the guardian ad litem (GAL), foster
  care caseworker, and Mother and Father in determining that TPR was in the best
  interest of the Children.Â  However, the family court noted:Â  "There
  is no doubt that Janice C[.] expresses her love and concern for her children.Â 
  However, she is unable to care for them.Â  Stanley E[.] professes love and
  concern for his child, but will not change his living situation in order to
  care for the child." Â During the termination hearing, the GAL
  testified TPR was in the Childrenâ€™s best interest because they "need[ed]
  some permanency." Â However, GAL admitted he never visited or interviewed
  Mother or Children.Â  The family court noted: "[GAL's] opinion is
  that the children are best served by being freed for adoption in order to be
  placed in a stable home with the opportunity to meet the special needs of each
  child."Â  In addition, Gloria Davis, the foster care caseworker, testified
  Mother failed to complete her treatment plan. Â Other evidence presented,
  however, demonstrates Mother was making progress toward completing her
  treatment plan and had completed all of the parenting classes. Â Â The family
  courtâ€™s order also terminated Fatherâ€™s parental rights as to N.C.Â  after
  finding termination was in the best interest of N.C. and the following
  statutory grounds: (1) Father severely neglected N.C. and it is unreasonable
  that the home can be made safe within twelve months; (2) Father abandoned N.C.;
  and (3) N.C. has been in foster care for fifteen out of the most recent twenty-two
  months.Â  Mother and Father appeal.
II.  MOTHERâ€™S APPEAL
A.  Standard of Review
Mother
  first argues the family court applied the incorrect standard of review.Â  Specifically, Mother contends the family court
  applied the preponderance of the evidence standard in terminating her parental
  rights instead of the proper clear and convincing standard.Â  We disagree.
Initially,
  we note the family courtâ€™s order provides: "Based upon an examination of
  the pleadings, consideration of all of the testimony and evidence presented,
  and the recommendations of the guardian ad litem for the minor child, I find
  that the evidence presented is clear and convincing, and from such
  evidence and testimony, I make the following findings . . . ." Â (emphasis added).Â  Based on this language, we find the family court applied the
  correct standard of review.Â  Furthermore, any error was harmless because we are
  determining our own findings from the record as to whether clear and convincing
  evidence supports the termination of parental rights.Â  See S.C. Depâ€™t
    of Soc. Servs. v. Headden, 354 S.C. 602, 609, 582 S.E.2d 419, 423 (2003).Â  
B.  Proofs of Service
Mother
  also argues the family court erred by referencing properly filed acceptances
  and affidavits of services in its TPR order where the proofs of service were
  not entered into evidence at the hearing.Â  We disagree.
Rule
  201, SCRE, governing the taking of judicial notice, provides as follows:

	(a) Scope of Rule. This rule governs only judicial notice of
  adjudicative facts.
	(b)
  Kinds of Facts. A judicially
  noticed fact must be one not subject to reasonable dispute in that it is either
  (1) generally known within the territorial jurisdiction of the trial court or
  (2) capable of accurate and ready determination by resort to sources whose
  accuracy cannot reasonably be questioned.
	. . .
	(f)
  Time of Taking Notice. Judicial
  notice may be taken at any stage of the proceeding . . . .


    When a court takes judicial notice of a fact it "admit[s] into
  evidence and consider[s], without proof of the facts, matters of common and
  general knowledge." Â Moss v. Aetna Life Ins. Co., 267 S.C. 370,
  377, 228 S.E.2d 108, 112 (1976) (citation omitted).Â  To be subjected to judicial
  notice, a fact must be of "such common knowledge that it is accepted by
  the general public without qualification or contention, or its accuracy may be
  ascertained by reference to readily available sources of indisputable
  reliability." Â Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 94, 561 S.E.2d 610,
  615 (Ct. App. 2002) (citation omitted).Â  Further, "a court can take judicial notice of its own records, files and proceedings for all
  proper purposes including facts established in its records."Â  Freeman
    v. McBee, 280 S.C. 490, 494, 313 S.E.2d 325, 327 (Ct. App. 1984).
Here, the family
  court took judicial notice of acceptances and affidavits of services.Â  These
  documents were filed with the family court; therefore, they were part of the
  record.Â  Accordingly, the family court did not err by referencing the documents
  in its order.Â  Furthermore, even if this court determines the family court
  erred by referencing the documents, any error was harmless because Mother does
  not argue any party was improperly served.
C.  TPR
Finally,
  Mother contends the family court erred by terminating her parental rights.Â  We
  agree.Â  

	The termination of the legal relationship between natural parents
  and a child presents one [of] the most difficult issues this Court is called
  upon to decide.Â  We exercise great caution in reviewing termination proceedings
  and will conclude termination is proper only when the evidence clearly and
  convincingly mandates such a result.

Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v.
  Cochran, 364 S.C. 621, 626, 614
  S.E.2d 642, 645 (2005).Â  
Procedures
  for TPR are governed by statute.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 63-7-2510 to
  2610 (Supp. 2008).Â  The purpose of the TPR statute is:

	to
  establish procedures for the reasonable and compassionate termination of
  parental rights where children are abused, neglected, or abandoned in order to
  protect the health and welfare of these children and make them eligible for
  adoption by persons who will provide a suitable home environment and the love
  and care necessary for a happy, healthful, and productive life.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 63-7-2510
  (Supp. 2008). 
The
  family court may order TPR upon a finding of one or more of the eleven
  statutory grounds and a finding that TPR is in the best interest of the child.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 63-7-2570 (Supp. 2008).Â  The TPR statute "must
  be liberally construed in order to ensure prompt judicial procedures for
  freeing minor children from the custody and control of their parents by
  terminating the parent-child relationship." S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 63-7-2620
  (Supp. 2008).
"If
  the family court finds that a statutory ground for [TPR] has been proven, it
  must then find that the best interests of the child would be served by
  [TPR]."Â  Doe v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 580, 578 S.E.2d 733,
  735 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  "In a termination of parental rights (TPR) case, the
  best interests of the children are the paramount consideration."Â  Id. at 579, 578 S.E.2d at 735.Â  "The
  interests of the child shall prevail if the child's interest and the parental
  rights conflict."Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 63-7-2620 (Supp. 2008).
In
  this case, there is no question that at least one of the eleven statutory
  grounds for TPR has been met.Â  It is undisputed Children have been in foster
  care since July 27, 2004 and have not lived with Mother since that date.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 63-7-2570(8) (Supp. 2008).Â  The question of whether TPR is in
  Childrenâ€™s best interest, however, is a more difficult issue.Â  
At
  the TPR hearing, Gloria Davis, a foster care caseworker, testified for DSS.Â  She
  testified Mother "cares for her Children, but does not know how to parent
  the children."Â  She stated Mother visited Children in foster care on a
  regular basis and rarely missed a visit.Â  She also provided nonmonetary support
  to Children, including food items and clothing.Â  Davis testified
  Children enjoyed interacting with Mother and recognized Mother as their mother.
  Although Davis maintained Mother failed to maintain adequate housing, Davis
  conceded she last visited Motherâ€™s home five months prior to the hearing and
  only observed the living room during that visit.Â  Davis added Mother failed to
  complete her treatment plan, explaining Mother refused services from the
  Department of Special Needs and failed to complete parenting classes. 
Other
  evidence presented at the hearing, however, demonstrates Mother was making
  progress toward completing her treatment plan.Â  Leteesa George, of the
  Department of Special Needs, testified Mother recently accepted services with
  the Department of Special Needs.Â  George added she was in the process of
  preparing Motherâ€™s intake packet to determine whether Mother was eligible for
  services.Â  In addition, Vanessa Boatwright, of Consulting Concepts,
  testified DSS referred Mother to Consulting Concepts for parenting classes.Â 
  Boatwright stated Mother completed all of the parenting classes and contributed
  to the classes.
Dr.
  Douglas Ritz, a clinical psychologist who evaluated Mother on February 9, 2007,
  also testified at the hearing.Â  He testified the evaluation lasted
  approximately two to three hours, and Ritz did not observe Mother taking care
  of Children.Â  Ritz opined Motherâ€™s "cognitive abilities came in the
  diagnostic category of mild mental retardation" and she functions at a
  second-grade level. Ultimately, he determined a person with Motherâ€™s
  characteristics could not adequately parent five children without some type of
  live-in help.Â  Â Â 
The
  GAL appointed to the case in 2006 testified although Mother loves Children,
  visited them, and provided in-kind support, he did not feel she was capable of
  caring for Children and meeting their needs.Â  He noted Motherâ€™s and Childrenâ€™s
  special needs.Â  GAL further testified Children had been in foster care for
  three years and were doing well.Â  He admitted he never visited or
  interviewed Mother or Children but recommended TPR because Children "need[ed]
  some permanency." Â However, he further testified that he had no
  objection to permanent foster care, which would allow the children to have a
  continuing relationship with their Mother, if no adoptive resource was
  available. 
A
  primary objective of the TPR statutes is to free children for the stability
  adoption can provide.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 63-7-2510 (Supp. 2008).Â  TPR would leave Children without a legal mother.Â  Reunification
  may never be a possibility given Motherâ€™s limitations.Â  However, reversing TPR
  will maintain Motherâ€™s parental rights and will allow Mother to continue
  visiting Children, while they remain in their current foster care home where
  they are receiving the services they need.Â  We hesitate to grant TPR when the
  GAL and Dr. Ritz never observed Mother interacting with her Children.Â 
  Furthermore, the record does not reflect and the GAL admitted he never visited
  or interviewed Mother or Children.Â  Therefore, we do not believe the GAL
  "conduct[ed] an independent assessment of the facts . . . ."Â  S.C.
  Code Â§ 63-11-510 (Supp. 2008).Â  We also note a discrepancy in the GAL's
  testimony.Â  Though he recommended TPR because Children need some permanency, he
  also recognized Mother loves her Children and has provided in-kind support.Â  
Because
  Childrenâ€™s best interests are the paramount consideration in a TPR action,
  under these facts, it appears the family court erred in finding termination of
  Motherâ€™s parental rights was in Childrenâ€™s best interests.Â  We see no harm in allowing
  Children to remain in their current placement, which would enable visitation
  between Mother and Children to continue.Â  Moreover, the record is devoid of any
  evidence that suitable adoptive parents have been identified.Â  Consequently, TPR
  will not provide future stability for Children.Â  Accordingly, we believe TPR is
  premature at this time based on the record before the court and reverse the
  family court's TPR of Mother.Â  
III.  FATHERâ€™S APPEAL 
A.   Standard of ReviewÂ  
Father
  argues the family court applied the incorrect standard of review.Â  Mother
  raised this very same issue in her brief, and it is addressed above.Â  As stated
  above, we affirm the family court as to this issue and find the family court applied the correct standard of
  review. Furthermore, any error was harmless because we are determining our own
  findings from the record as to whether clear and convincing evidence supports
  the termination of parental rights.Â  See S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v.
    Headden, 354 S.C. at 609, 582 S.E.2d at 423.Â  
B.  Proofs of Service 
Father
  argues the family court erred by referencing properly filed acceptances and
  affidavits of services in its TPR order where the proofs of service were not
  entered into evidence at the hearing.Â  Father, however, does not argue any
  party was improperly served.Â  This issue was raised by Mother and is addressed
  above.Â  We affirm.Â  
C.  Treatment Plan
Father
  argues the family court erred by ruling DSS was not required to offer him a
